H0.text: The infected animals do not show symptoms, which explains why diseases transmitted through their bites are not considered contagious diseases.

H1.text: The person in direct contact is the only one infected in diseases transmitted through the bites of infected animals, which is why they are not considered contagious diseases.

H2.text: Humans do not become sick from animal diseases, which is why diseases transmitted through bites of infected animals are not considered contagious.

H3.text: The diseases are treatable with antibiotics is the reason why diseases transmitted through the bites of infected animals are not considered contagious diseases.

A4.text: Secondary transmission encompasses a category of diseases of animal origin in which the actual transmission to humans is a rare event but, once it has occurred, human-to-human transmission maintains the infection cycle for some period of time.

A5.text: Animal populations are the principal reservoir of the pathogen and horizontal infection in humans is rare.

A6.text: treatment is almost never effective and mortality is over 99%

A7.text: no such cases have ever been documented

A8.text: The advent of antibiotics improved the outcome of bite wound infections.

A9.text: Antibiotics to prevent infection are recommended for dog and cat bites of the hand, and human bites if they are more than superficial.
